# Chapter 18

Deadpool halts mid-stride, katanas balanced lazily on his shoulders, staring at the chaos of spiraling staircases and sideways hallways. “Well, MC Escher called—he wants his deposit back. And I can’t even find the front desk.”

Morty scurries behind him, eyes stretched as far as panic can pull them. “W-where even *are* we? This feels like the inside of a math test I slept through—if the numbers had fangs!”

Rick steadies himself as the floor ripples. Or maybe it’s the world that’s unhinged. “We’re in the Meta-Maze, Morty. Imagine a multiversal firewall with an inferiority complex. It’s a Rubik’s Cube with attitude—try to solve it and it flips you the bird.”

Deadpool leaps, landing with a twist on what should be a wall but instantly becomes his floor. He jazz-hands over at Rick and Morty, now cockeyed against gravity. “If my childhood dreams ever needed proof, here I am: moonwalking up a paradox. Next stop, musical number!”

Morty swallows and follows, steps unsteady as up, down, and sideways blend. He stops. “Gramps, do you see *that*?” He points. A corridor flickers: comic panels looping and rewinding, overlapping versions of themselves arguing in cartoon dialogue balloons.

Rick squints, futzes with the portal gun. “Just the maze remixing our worst decisions, Morty. Morrison fever dream times editorial panic attack.”

Then, booming laughter. The whole maze shudders, stairs squirming as a voice echoes: “Welcome, meta-victims! Ready to wander your own punchlines, or brave the core of the joke?”

Deadpool twirls his swords, eyes alight. “Lost and loving it, Mystery Host! Unless you’re a metaphor, in which case, get in line—my therapist is still recovering.”

Rick raises a hand, keeping Morty close. “Heads on a swivel. In a maze this meta, the only way out is to deliver a punchline nobody expects.”

They inch onward. The corridor writhes, canned laughter trailing after like static.

The staircase shifts; banisters turn to spiky question marks. Morty shudders. “Are we even in the right *layer* of reality? My knees feel inside-out, and every door looks like it wants a snack.”

Rick’s portal gun hums, projecting a spaghetti tangle of timelines overhead. “Right now, we’re less stable than a Marvel plot during crossover season. If the meta gets its way, we’re punchlines with no setup.”

Deadpool pokes a doorknob. It giggles, snaps at his blade. “Finally—a door more aggressive than my last ex’s lawyer.” He tries to wink at a non-existent camera, then shrugs. “Or am I winking at you?”

Wall edges liquefy, dripping down. Comic-style letters appear in the air: **LAUGH TRACK MALFUNCTION!**

Rick curses, portal gun blipping erratically. “Crap—they’re boosting the meta to dangerous levels. If we can’t stabilize the punchline matrix, we’ll end up as one-note jokes. Spaceballs, Act II.”

Deadpool, swords akimbo: “No worries! I thrive under comedic tension. Or any tension, really.” He glances upward. “Bonus points for the panel glitch callback—see, Chapter One did matter.”

Morty, voice hitching: “Can we *please* skip the part where all of us get rewritten as whoopee cushions?”

Rick retunes the portal gun. “If I can recalibrate a narrative ‘bolt,’ maybe we can hack out. Last time I tried this, it was Pomplamoose at Burning Man—wait, nevermind. Focus!”

Before another word, the floor peels open—becoming a conveyor belt plastered with abandoned punchlines: “Take my reality—please!” / “That’s what she said!” / “Schrodinger’s joke!” The maze flushes them forward, canned laughter swelling.

Deadpool paddles with his katana, steering them through halls lined in echoing panels—the same warehouse from Chapter 1, Deadpool’s own voice looping, distorting: “If I turn into an anime girl—editor’s fault!”

Morty clings to Deadpool’s arm, barely breathing. “What if we never get out? What if we just… keep looping—stuck in our own reruns until we disappear?”

Deadpool claps him on the shoulder—just for a moment, honest. “Hey, Morty, my knees *always* feel inside-out. Occupational hazard. Comedy or tragedy? It’s all timing. The punchline only lands if you stick around for it.”

Rick, hopping between steps on a Möbius staircase that refuses to end, says, “We’re out of time—need a genre-bomb, something big enough to short the narrative. Something *nobody* expects in a crisis comic—”

Deadpool’s hand shoots up. “Musical number! If a Disney song can reset a villain, maybe we can break through.”

Morty groans. “Aww, geez. This is like theater camp nightmares all over again.”

Rick grins, wild and defiant. “Fine. Let’s fry the narrative circuits.”

Right then, a piano drops from nowhere, spotlighted. Deadpool cracks his knuckles, bows deeply. “Break a leg, fellas. But not on these stairs—OSHA’s watching.”

Rick hammers the keys, Deadpool belts a song about cosmic chaos, redemption, and the indestructible power of terrible puns. Morty’s off-key but earnest. Their discordant melody prickles the maze—the stairs twitch, the looping walls glitch, the floating **LAUGH TRACK MALFUNCTION** flickers and reforms as: *HEARTFELT*.

Everything holds—just for a beat. Reality itself seems to listen, breath held.

Somewhere in the dark, the voice returns—a shade softer, uncertainty threading its laugh.

And now the world, meta and chaotic, waits—hungry for a punchline wild enough to break it free.
